title: Sanctuary City Mayors Fire Back After Sessions Tells Them To Obey The Law
text:
Sanctuary City Mayors Fire Back After Sessions Tells Them To Obey The Law "...disheartening..." Share on Facebook Share Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
After Attorney General Jeff Sessions told America’s sanctuary cities they would have to start living by the rules or face the fiscal consequences, mayors of some of the largest communities that shelter illegal immigrants breathed defiance as they vowed not to bend in a war of wills with the Trump administration. 
“ We will fight to protect the safety and dignity of all Angelenos, and we will work closely with our representatives in Congress to make sure that Los Angeles does not go without federal resources that help protect millions of people every day,” Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti said. 
On Monday, Sessions backed up a January executive order from President Donald Trump by telling sanctuary cities — loosely defined as local governments that refuse to cooperate with federal rules requiring illegal immigrants to be handed over to federal immigration authorities — by warning local communities they would be forfeiting federal funding if they do not obey the law. Advertisement - story continues below Trump Signs Executive Order To Scrap Clean Power Plan, End ‘War On Coal’ 
Garcetti said that Sessions would be the one in the wrong if he acted. 
“Slashing funds for first-responders, for our port and airport, for counterterrorism, crime-fighting and community-building serves no one — not this city, not the federal government, not the American people,” he said. 
Although Sessions said cities seeking federal Department of Justice grant funding would be required to commit to uphold immigration laws, Garcetti said forcing them to do that would be “unconstitutional.” Advertisement - story continues below 
Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel said his city continues “to welcome entrepreneurs, immigrants, and I would just say think of it this way: Half the new businesses in Chicago and the state of Illinois come from immigrants, nearly half.” Mayor Rahm Emanuel brands Trump’s sanctuary city threat a ‘bit of a joke,’ @fspielman reports https://t.co/KQkv0ye3Us pic.twitter.com/GyXFuNx7D4 
— Chicago Sun-Times (@Suntimes) March 28, 2017 
Boston Mayor Marty Walsh said illegal immigrants “can use my office. They can use any office in this building.” We won’t back down from protecting New Yorkers from terror – or from an overzealous administration fixated on xenophobia and division. https://t.co/HITtsr52xm 
— Bill de Blasio (@NYCMayor) March 27, 2017 Advertisement - story continues below 
New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio said obeying federal immigration rules would “undermine public safety and make our neighborhoods less safe.” 
Sessions on Monday made it clear that leaders of sanctuary cities needed to act. 
“I strongly urge our nation’s states and cities and counties to consider carefully the harm they are doing to their citizens by refusing to enforce our immigration laws, and to rethink these policies,” he said. “Such policies make their cities and states less safe, public safety as well as national security are at stake, and put them at the risk of losing federal dollars.” 
He termed the mayors’ defiance “disheartening.” 
“The American people want and deserve a lawful system of immigration that keeps us safe, and one that serves national interests,” Sessions said. “This expectation is reasonable, just, and our government has the duty to meet it and we will meet it.” 
Trump signaled his support for Sessions Tuesday when he mentioned Sessions’ Monday announcement during meeting with the leaders of the Fraternal Order of Police. 
“That was a very important thing you did, and frankly, a very popular thing. It’s great to have you with us,” he told Sessions, who attended the event. What do you think? Scroll down to comment below. Suggest a correction Share on Facebook Share Tweet Email Email Print Popular Right Now
